Dear Bruno,

I am not familiar with C2 mechanism but in principle the veloc=
ity of
38.2 cm/s looks good because experimental laminar velocities for CH4=
-air
change in range 34-43 cm/s. For higher pressures I would prefer GRI-2.=
1
Mech. It gives better fit with experiments. Maximum flame temperature
can=
 not help you. I think it does not depend on mechanism because it is
thermo=
dynamic function. 

Best regards,
Mike

-----Original Message-----
From: ca=
ntera@yahoogroups.com [mailto:cantera@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf

To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
Subj=
ect: [cantera] different flame speeds with different reaction
mechanisms


=
Dear Cantera users,

I am unexperiemented with this great software and hope=
 I will find 
some help with the following dilemma.

To compute the laminar=
 flame speed, I use the file adiabatic_flame.py

For a stoichiometric CH4/a=
ir mixture, using the mechanism GRI30, I 
obtain a flame speed of 38.2cm/s
=
However, when I use the C2 mechanism of San Diego University, the 
result i=
s 32.5cm/s
Why such a difference? Those two mechanisms have anyway good 
ag=
reement on flame temperature and species gradients.

Here is the modificati=
on I made to incorporate the San diego 
mechanism in the .py file:

gas =3D=
 IdealGasMix('san_diego.cti')
#gas =3D GRI30('Mix')
gas.addTransportModel('=
Mix')

Moreover, those results seem to me under-estimating the CH4/air 
lam=
inar flame speed. I would have expected values closer to 40cm/s.

Thank you=
 very much for your help and comments.

Bruno










 
Yahoo! Groups Lin=
ks
